g.text: 28. Galeotti, P., Rubolini, D., Sacchi, R. & Fasola, M. Global changes and animal phenotypic responses: melanin-based plumage redness
of scops owls increased with temperature and rainfall during the last century.
29. Galván, I., Rodríguez-Martínez, S. & Carrascal, L. M. Dark pigmentation limits thermal niche position in birds.
30. Galván, I., Palacios, D. & Negro, J. J. The bare head of the Northern bald ibis (Geronticus eremita) fulfills a thermoregulatory
31. Somero, G. N. The physiology of climate change: How potentials for acclimatization and genetic adaptation will determine ‘winners’
32. DuBay, S. G. & Fuldner, C. C. Bird specimens track 135 years of atmospheric black carbon and environmental policy.
33. Meineke, E. K., Davies, T. J., Daru, B. H. & Davis, C. C. Biological collections for understanding biodiversity in the Anthropocene.
Philos. Trans. R. Soc. Lond. B. Biol. Sci
34. Mason, N. A. & Unitt, P. Rapid phenotypic change in a native bird population following conversion of the Colorado Desert to
35. Cui, X. & Graf, H.-F. Recent land cover changes on the Tibetan Plateau: a review.
36. McGraw, K.J., Mackillop. E.A., Dale, J. and Hauber, M.E. Different colors reveal different information: how nutritional stress affects
the expression of melanin- and structurally based ornamental plumage.
. Species Coextinctions and the Biodiversity Crisis.
38. Parmesan, C. Ecological and Evolutionary Responses to Recent Climate Change.
39. Bellard, C., Bertelsmeier, C., Leadley, P., Thuiller, W. & Courchamp, F. Impacts of climate change on the future of biodiversity.
40. Travis, J., Delgado, M. & Bocedi, G. Dispersal and species’ responses to climate change.
41. Oostra, V., Saastamoinen, M., Zwaan, B. J. & Wheat, C. W. Strong phenotypic plasticity limits potential for evolutionary responses
42. San-Jose, L. M. & Roulin, A. Genomics of coloration in natural animal populations.
43. Ducatez, S., Giraudeau, M., Thébaud, C. & Jacquin, L. Colour polymorphism is associated with lower extinction risk in birds.
44. Delhey, K., Delhey, V., Kempenaers, B. & Peters, A. A practical framework to analyze variation in animal colors using visual models.
45. Doucet, S. M. & Hill, G. E. Do museum specimens accurately represent wild birds? A case study of carotenoid, melanin, and
structural colours in long-tailed manakins Chiroxiphia linearis.
46. Peterson, T. C. & Vose, R. S. An overview of the global historical climatology network temperature data base.
47. BirdLife International and Handbook of the Birds of the World. Bird species distribution maps of the world. Version 7.0. Available
Because this work would have not been possible without her help, making the our journeys always easy and
enjoyable, we are warmly grateful to Maria Miranda. We thank all the personnel working at the Museo Civico di
Zoologia (Rome, Italy), MUSE (Trento, Italy), Naturhistorisches Museum Wien (Vienna, Austria), Museum für
Naturkunde (Berlin, Germany), Zoologische Staatssammlung München (Munich, Germany), American Museum
of Natural History (New York, USA) and The Field Museum of Natural History (Chicago, USA) who warmly
welcomed and helped us during this study. In particular, we thank H.-M. Berg, M.C. Deflorian, P. Eckhoff, F.
Fraticelli, S. Frahnert A. Gamauf, L. Garetano, M. Hennen, C. Marangoni and M. Unsöld. We also thank S. Birks
from Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture, Seattle, USA, for providing further sample material for
genetic analysis. Special thanks to G. Bombieri, C. Camacho, G. Orizaola, J. Martinez Padilla, V. Penteriani and
J. Mayor Resano for comments on earlier drafts, G. Bombieri for the drawings in figures and P. Laiolo for her
assisstance with phylogenetic analyses. The work was financially supported by the (a) British Ecological Society
(#5710 / 6754); (b) Spanish Ministry of Sciences, Innovation and Universities (#CGL2016-79764-P); and (c) a
Spanish Ramon y Cajal grant RYC-2014-16263 (MMD). Molecular phylogenetic analyses were supported by
M.M.D. conceived the ideas and designed methodology, analysed the data and led the writing of the manuscript;
M.M.D. and C.B. collected the data; J.M. and M.P. built the phylogenetic tree. All authors contributed critically to
the drafts and gave final approval for publication.
The authors declare no competing interests.
is available for this paper at
and requests for materials should be addressed to M.d.M.D.
